Text: Touched down in D.C. with Archie in tow. Excited that he'll be standing next to me when I am sworn in tomorrow. https://t.co/jJ5iIkN9ui

Headed back to DC, frustrated that the President won’t come to the table to end the government shutdown, but proud that tomorrow I’ll be sworn in with a historic number of women who will be serving in Congress.

The Trump Admin tried to quietly make a proposal that’d seriously harm our health when families were busy during the holidays. Let’s not let them slip this under the rug. Spread the word and speak out against this atrocious idea. https://t.co/XttE4lmCTX

Today I was sworn in as Senator of Minnesota for the second time in one year. An incredible experience. I’m fired up and ready to get things done for you, your family, and all those who call our state home. It’s an honor to work for you. https://t.co/c4kivnabIb
Hey Minnesota, Archie here. Excited to be in Washington D.C. for Tina’s swearing in today. Wearing this special tie for her big day! https://t.co/MairYPSWMG

It’s day 14 of Trump’s shutdown. Some ppl who could be hurt most: low-wage federal contractor employees.

They aren’t getting paid—& haven’t received BACK PAY after previous shutdowns. 

I'll be introducing a bill to right that wrong. This is abt fairness.
https://t.co/wrMF0dPQUg

Fed up with big pharma putting profits ahead of consumers, forcing people (maybe you) to pay sky-high Rx prices? Me too. I’m committed to tackling this problem. Thanks @CBSNews for covering the ↑ cost of #insulin & MN @NSmithholt12 for sharing her story. https://t.co/9lQxZbFb51
The Trump Administration is using federal workers as bargaining chips for a political symbol and giving themselves pay raises. What kind of leadership is this?!https://t.co/GB9Rvk23ot

Sat down w/ @MSNBC’s @chrislhayes to discuss Trump’s shutdown—a complete waste for tax payers. I’m working on a bill to help low-wage workers who’ve been furloughed bc of the shutdown get the pay they deserve. This is abt fairness & making sure ppl can provide for their families. https://t.co/YA4DIb48L4
Happy 91st Birthday to my dear friend Walter Mondale! https://t.co/3t4mnbLj5t

Stop thinking only about yourself @realdonaldtrump. And stop using federal workers and contractors, who need a paycheck to pay their bills, as bargaining chips for a political symbol. And also, your shutdown shouldn’t be used to threaten families who count on SNAP to feed kids.

One of the great honors of my professional life has been to work with @GovMarkDayton to build a better Minnesota. He is a true public servant, fearless, compassionate, funny, and a man of integrity. Mark, your state is grateful for your service! https://t.co/kiGD9Sra3f

I’ve worked with State Rep & County Commissioner Tom Rukavina, planned with him, argued with him, laughed with him, and organized with him. I never doubted that he always put his beloved Iron Range and the Rangers who built their lives there first. Irreplaceable. He’ll be missed.

And @GovTimWalz and @LtGovFlanagan, thank you for stepping up for this state that we love! We need your energy, determination, talent and leadership to build #OneMinnesota. Congrats on your inauguration today.

.@senatemajldr can't just outsource the Senate to the President. There are bills sitting on the Senate floor RIGHT NOW that could resolve large portions of Trump's shutdown. He should call for a vote so we can end this terrible situation. https://t.co/eItgGdSfM5

It’s day 18 of Trump’s shutdown and I want to hear how it's affecting Minnesotans. If you’re a federal worker or a contract worker, or even just a taxpayer who wants its government to work, please comment below, send me a direct message, or call my office at (651) 221-1016. https://t.co/evsWOmSsBG

I’ll soon be discussing the latest news re: Trump’s shutdown on @Morning_Joe. I’m working on a bill to help low-wage fed contract workers who’ve been furloughed bc of this shutdown get the pay they deserve. They haven’t received back pay after previous shutdowns. That’s unfair. https://t.co/ZgfQ6Tiair

Some of the people getting hit the hardest by Trump’s shutdown are low-wage federal contract employees. They’re not getting paid & haven’t received back pay after previous shutdowns. I’ll be on @Morning_Joe tmrw at 7:40 am ET to discuss what I’m doing to right that wrong.

I’m moved by how bravely Nicole continues to share her story. She is working to make sure Americans can afford their insulin & I helped bring her to Washington so she could share her story with others.
 
Please read this & let's work to ↓ Rx drug prices.

As someone who has been involved in a lot of negotiations—I can tell you this: walking out of a meeting gets you nowhere. Mr. President, walking out is no way to end your government shutdown. Come to the table and work across the aisle so we can end this terrible situation.

This winter I brought our chocolate lab puppy, Moose, up to the North Shore. He saw a deer, played in the snow, and spotted Lake Superior for the first time. And I saw an eagle! Moments like this remind me why winter in Minnesota is so special. #OnlyInMN

This shutdown is a waste & increasingly harmful. We need to reopen the government. I stand in solidarity with the 1000s of workers and contractors going without pay, so I will be donating my Senate salary for the duration of the current shutdown to The Advocates for Human Rights.
Tonight we heard the same thing we’ve been hearing from the President for two years. He again offered no solutions. What remains is people are hurting. We need to reopen the government.

Day 19 of shutdown. Some 800K federal workers won't get paid on Friday. Low-wage fed contract workers aren’t getting paid either—& they haven’t received back pay after past shutdowns. I spoke to @MPR's @CathyWurzer about how I'm working to right that wrong:https://t.co/jCoipHIKiV

Glad @CNN had Brian, a Minnesota federal employee, on air to talk about his shutdown experience. I talked to Brian yesterday & his story is worth a listen. He raises a key point: there are ways we can reopen the govt & we should do that. I urge you to watch this clip & share.
@toreyvanoot Glad you’re all caught up! Moose says hello.

It’s day 20 of Trump’s shutdown. The longer it lasts, the more critical it is to secure back pay for federal contractor workers. I’m working on a bill to make sure this happens bc they haven't received back pay after past shutdowns. Pressing the Trump Admin to back this idea too. https://t.co/hQomN1UpkL

I want to share a letter I read on the Senate floor today. It’s not long, so I encourage you to read the whole thing. Read here: https://t.co/hDJFwOwXEL

#ShutdownStories https://t.co/PmM16E5eLY

Like I’ve said before: Moms need to work, and babies need to eat. As we work towards creating economic opportunity for all, we cannot neglect breastfeeding working moms. Every workplace should be family-friendly. https://t.co/8WZLqhmEWe
Minnesota—the state of innovation. We invented the pacemaker, waterskiing, the Honeycrisp apple, and thanks to this Minnesotan, the Clitherall palm tree.
@StribGuy @stribrooks Ha! This makes me wonder if other reporters call me from parking lots. Thanks for connecting, @stribrooks. Always a pleasure.
800,000 federal workers didn’t get paid today because of President Trump’s shutdown. Some still got paystubs. Here’s one from a Minnesota air traffic controller. Unbelievable. https://t.co/6klbKp8qgH

“At the end of the day, the impact on these lower-wage workers, folks that are making $20, $22 an hour—as one woman said to me, ‘If I don’t get paid, I don’t pay my bills’—seems to be the most urgent issue and also, in my mind, just basic fairness.”
https://t.co/BW4ND0fi50

Today 800,000 federal workers aren’t receiving a paycheck because of Trump’s shutdown, including 1000s of Minnesotans. In an hour, I’ll be with Minnesota federal workers at @mspairport to hear their #shutdownstories. I’ll be streaming the event live so you can listen, too.

I’m at @mspairport to update folks on the latest shutdown news, and hear Minnesota federal workers describe their shutdown experiences. Their stories are worth a listen. Watch live: https://t.co/d1R6XJf5wz
Glad we’re working together on this bipartisan effort, Senator @JerryMoran.

Farmers can’t apply for fed loans, ppl who rely on food assistance may get cut off & some U of M research buildings closed. Oh—& almost 5K fed workers & contractors in MN are going w/o pay. Can this nightmare plz end? Time to open the govt. RT if you agree.https://t.co/mGK2DLucWp

Federal workers have essentially been held hostage by Trump’s shutdown. Yesterday federal workers shared their #ShutdownStories at MSP Airport. Let me tell you—the human toll is real. There are bipartisan ways to #EndTheShutdown & we must take them up. https://t.co/XaD5lGbDnQ

When I visited Tornillo last month, I was told not to talk to the detained kids because it would disrupt them. The *real* disruption was detaining these kids in the first place. I’m glad to see they’ve been released. Important progress.
https://t.co/rbEAaUK1GG
President Trump’s secrecy about his interactions with Putin are completely out of bounds and outrageous. What did he do with these notes? What is he hiding from Americans? https://t.co/HiWl9vJhxp

This is what leadership looks like in 2019 — strong, resilient, courageous, wise, powerful. These colleagues fill me with optimism. https://t.co/H5QYosQqA0

A federal worker who lives in River Falls, WI says she’s being forced to ration insulin to treat her Type 1 diabetes because she isn’t getting paid. We MUST open the federal government. https://t.co/8gQ0h5c63D

The human toll of Trump’s shutdown is very real. 

Derek, a Farmington air traffic controller, wrote me, “It is quite ridiculous that an air traffic controller would be affected by political games. Take us off the bargaining table.” 

Couldn’t agree more. #EndTheShutdown https://t.co/Ko1l0BmnZM

#ICYMI: Trump Administration finally listened to warnings of health issues at Tornillo detention facility and removed all children from the site. 

I visited Tornillo last month and what I saw goes against our values. 

https://t.co/L0S99IVRBZ

US AG nominee William Barr has an alarming record of abusing civil rights. And if confirmed, he'll have great power to oversee important issues including voting rights and criminal justice reform. Oh, and the Mueller investigation. Watch his hearing today. It matters.

Congrats on the new job, Sam. Thanks for your work to keep Minnesotans up to date on all things Washington. And thanks for being the emcee and breaking a tie at my first Minnesota Congressional Hotdish Competition.

A Minnesotan w/ cancer who's affected by the shutdown wrote me, “Instead of worrying abt getting me healthy, we have been wracked w/ thoughts of ‘What if this continues & we can’t pay our mortgage?’ ‘How will we pay for my medical bills in the immediate future?'" #EndTheShutdown https://t.co/L2a0gRCUKk

#EndTheShutdown https://t.co/04RU54nc9e

Trump’s shutdown is imposing a massive burden on communities to speed up getting SNAP funds to Americans before a Jan 21 deadline. People who sign up after that may not get food support & March funding is in limbo. Basic human needs like food should NOT be jeopardized like this.

Read this story and be angry, and then speak out. It is immoral to rip these immigrant children away from their parents.

Fed contractor employees—janitors, cafeteria workers & security guards—have bills to pay just like everyone else. But they're not being paid during the shutdown & haven't received back pay in the past. It's unfair. So I intro'd a bill to right that wrong. https://t.co/qfhoGlByZe

When a company fakes going out of business to avoid paying their employees, it's stealing. That's what happened to @Teamsters120 members. Because they had their union to fight for them, today they got paid. When people organize for fairness and justice, they raise us all up.

Too often low-& mid-income fed contract workers are invisible. These are ppl who provide security or clean office spaces. And get this: many aren’t getting paid during the shutdown AND haven't received back pay after past ones. I intro'd a bill to fix that.https://t.co/G1fNdt53z2

I have some thoughts on what is unfolding in Syria, and why Trump’s leadership is so dangerous for our nation. 

Let me explain:

A true pleasure to work on this with you, Senator.

I urge Mitch McConnell to allow the Senate to take up the Resolution condemning the President’s decision, which passed the House this week with wide bipartisan support. The guns may have stopped for now, but the President’s leadership remains clearly dangerous for our nation.
This is not a game show, it is literally life or death, and the consequences of this dangerous decision have played out with terrible speed.
Whenever the guns stop firing this is good news, and we should all hope that the violence unleashed by the US withdrawal from the Syrian borderlands stops for good.
After a breathtaking week, we are now told that Vice President Pence has brokered a temporary “pause” in Syria, on terms that effectively hand Turkey a victory while forcing the Kurds to surrender.

Kurdish civilians have lost their lives because of the President’s unilateral, impulsive decision. 100s of ISIS terrorists & their families are free because of his decision.

Because of the President’s decision, Russia, Iran, Syria’s murderous leader Assad, and ISIS are stronger.

We live in a dangerous world. 

These dangers may seem to be thousands of miles away on the map. But if there’s one thing we should have learned over these last few years, it’s that long-distance danger can erupt close to home with no warning.

Trump’s recent decision to peremptorily withdraw US troops from Syria, with no plan to keep ISIS and terrorism under control, blindsiding our friends and allies, as well as our military and diplomatic service corps, makes the world a much more dangerous place, for Americans.

The President has been impeached. The question before the United States Senate is whether he should be removed from office.

That is a solemn responsibility and I am going to be taking it very seriously as we move forward.
Every day during the impeachment trial I’ll be taking notes, which I’ll share some of here.  Yesterday was day 1.

As the snow blankets Minnesota today, remaining hopeful that everyone can come back to the table soon in the interests of public safety and create an arrangement that gives workers the rights they deserve. https://t.co/jEFcvvheRq
In the Senate cloakrooms we now have carefully labeled cubbies to put our phones, iPads and smart watches aside while we go onto the floor. You can tell it’s hard for some of us to leave them there.

Looking out at my colleagues, I was struck by how rare it is that we are all on the floor together, sitting down, and focused on one thing. What would the Senate be like if we came together like this more often?
When Roberts came onto the floor the air changed. He looked, not pained, exactly, but as if he also felt the weight of history.
From where I sit, close to the doors in the second row of seats, I can see the faces of most of my colleagues: serious, focused, aware that the country is watching.

When the House managers came onto the floor, I felt the weight of history, and a small catch in my throat. 

It was a relief to hear @RepAdamSchiff present the articles dispassionately, clearly, and rationally. We are all wondering what the President’s lawyers will bring.

After lunch, the women were thinking logistics. 

It’s freezing in the chamber, should I bring a shawl? One of my colleagues plans to wear long underwear. The stools under our desks are helpful - the chairs of the Senate were designed for the likes of Abe Lincoln.

Senate staff on both sides of the aisle made sure we all lined up to sign the oath in the correct order. That was the only time all day that Democrats and Republicans mixed in together. We need to mix more.

Today, on Dr. King’s birthday, our job is to dream a different reality—through the power of coming together to celebrate something bigger than us—and work for freedom and justice and a nation that fulfills that promise. #MartinLutherKingJrDay

Just reading proposed GOP impeachment trial rules, which are ridiculous. 

There’s nothing in this resolution that requires hearing witnesses or admitting evidence—which is unlike any trial I’ve ever seen.

Then, two day, 24-hour marathons for presenting each side. Would you want your lawyer to be required to represent you under these circumstances?

It’s outrageous and a clear sign McConnell has no intention of holding the fair trial that Americans expect.

As promised, I have some more of my notes from the impeachment trial.

By 6 p.m. on the first day, you can start to see some themes:

The House managers today relentlessly plowed through questions about witnesses and documents, and asked us essentially "Why WOULDN'T you want to know this? Why WOULDN'T you want to see the documents?"

I agree.

I’m thinking as I’m writing this:

1) We should be rigorously prepared.

2) We shouldn’t be afraid of the facts and…

The President's lawyers seemed to be speaking to an audience of one. On questions of whether the Senate should call for witnesses and documents, they talked about Mueller, Pelosi, and Schiff.

Sometimes it came off as a bit incoherent. They read from notes and seemed unprepared.

It's a good strategy, said one of my colleagues, to "pre-unwrap" cough lozenges to keep from making noise.

There is tea, coffee, and treats in the cloakroom.

And THEN, graciously allow a debate on whether witnesses should be called, even though the trial is basically over. All the while, talk about fairness and hope America doesn’t notice.

I think America is noticing.
3) McConnell's move to table seems designed to protect his members from a "no" vote on including documents and witnesses for this trial, but I bet Americans will see what's really happening here.

Day 2, after a long night yesterday, and you can feel people settling into this new world of hours sitting on the Senate floor, listening and taking notes. And maybe a catnap or two (not naming names).
1) The facts aren’t really in dispute. Even the President’s lawyers haven’t challenged them so far.
I’m keeping notes in a red notebook—kind of a stream of consciousness of quotes, observations, and things to remember. I’m starting to think about questions I want to ask.

3) The distrustful way Rudy Giuliani has pursued the President’s private political interests, mixing with foreign policy in ways that can only be described as corrupt and antithetical to American values.

The House managers’ presentation, led by Congressman Adam Schiff, was a strong summation of the facts and the core issues the Senate faces. Now the House managers are plowing through the timeline and key facts.
We aren’t done for today just yet, but here are my thoughts:

2) It’s compelling to see how many facts link to Russia—the false theory that Ukraine, and not Russia, interfered in our 2016 election; how withholding aid weakened Ukraine in its fight with Russia; and how Russia interfered in the 2016 election to benefit Donald Trump; and

Lastly, I will say that watching the tapes of the President INVITING foreign interference in our elections—including from China—I asked myself, “is this a big deal?”

And I’ve come to the conclusion that yes, it is a very big deal.
I’m sharing my notes each day of the impeachment trial to help give folks a sense of what it’s like to be in the Senate during this historic moment—here’s last night’s:

Little more than halfway through Day #3. The Senate Chaplin began his opening prayer by urging us not just to hear but to also practice empathetic attentiveness. & to remember our friendships in the Senate. The Chaplin can always be counted on to appeal to our higher principles.

Just a reminder: in this great country our loyalty is to our Constitution and the rule of law, not any one leader. That’s what makes us a democracy, not a monarchy.
 
Thank you Lt. Colonel Vindman for showing us what that looks like. https://t.co/RMTWPqmd11

The House managers provided an excellent review of the constitutional rationale, history and precedent for impeachment for a President’s abuse of power. Even my colleagues with law degrees found it fascinating and full of good information.

One other thing: This morning before the Trial started, I reviewed a classified document with a statement from Vice President Pence’s senior aide, describing a telephone conversation between the Vice President and Ukrainian President Zelensky.

I can’t comment on the content of the document. What I can say is classifying a document solely because it contains embarrassing or damaging information is not a good reason.

I’m heading back on the floor for another several hours.

The White House lawyers argue in their 171-page brief that abuse of power is not impeachable. Let’s just say it’s hard to find a legal expert to support their position. But we’ll learn more about that when they begin their presentation.

Day #4, & I’m providing just a short note today because I’m taking my dinner break—30 minutes!—to celebrate my husband Archie’s 65th birthday. I’m usually in Washington without Archie, so it’s a real treat to have him here.

(1/6) Day #5 was a short day, just two hours of presentation from the President’s lawyers. After the session I went up to the gallery with my colleagues Tammy Duckworth, Jeff Merkley, and Leader Chuck Schumer to do a quick press response to the proceedings.

I’m working long hours, so Archie is coming to the Capitol and my colleague Senator Pat Leahy has offered his historic Capitol Hill office for a brief celebration. Thank you Pat, and happy birthday Archie.

(5/6) I’ve never been a member of a jury before—I’ve never even been called for jury duty. But it never dawned on me that my 1st trial would be in the U.S. Senate, & it would not include even this most basic element—witnesses, & ability for both sides to cross examine witnesses.
(3/6) What was interesting to me is how their presentation makes the case even stronger for why this trial needs witnesses and the documents.

Tomorrow the President’s counsel will take up their presentation. I’ll let you know my impressions. In the meantime, thinking of questions I want answers to, & I continue to hope we will hear from witnesses & see documents that will allow us to know the truth. Which is our right.

(6/6) On the good side, the President’s lawyers were civil and measured, which I think will help us all listen with the “empathetic attentiveness” that the Senate Chaplin has encouraged.

It will be good to have a day or so to think on all this, and clear my head for next week.

(4/6) If the President’s lawyers really believe the witnesses we’ve heard from so far don’t have all the facts about what happened here, why not hear from the witnesses, and see the documents, that could clear all this up? I don’t think this question is going to go away.
(2/6) After three days of comprehensive, thorough review of the facts and evidence from the House Managers, the President’s lawyers tried to to poke holes in the House Managers’ arguments.

Today Senators filed onto the floor of the United States Senate for the last time in this trial of impeachment. One  by one we voted, twice, on whether President Trump should be removed from office. (1/7)

I've asked myself whether I'd have voted to remove a President of my own party had they abused their power for personal, political benefit, damaging our elections & nat'l security in the process. It’s easy to say yes when the choice is hypothetical.

But the answer is yes. (3/7)

The truth is that I see more signs of common ground, hope and determination in Minnesota than I do the fractures of division, distrust and partisanship. That is a foundation for us all to build on going forward. (7/7)
It was not a suspenseful moment, but if felt as weighty as when I first raised my right hand and pledged to provide impartial justice. I know that is what I did. (2/7)
Now, we go forward. This trial has changed us, but it doesn’t change the core value of America that no one is above the law, including and most especially the President. (4/7)

After this vote, the work of reinforcing the American values of fairness and justice will continue. We have a lot of work to do, but democracy is hard work, and I know that Minnesotans are up to it. (6/7)
(2/4) The number one issue I hear about from Minnesotans is the high cost of health care, and skyrocketing prescription drug prices.

There is nothing inevitable about democracy. It’s not a natural state, it’s a state we have to fight for. The fight for democracy and our Constitution has chosen us in this moment and it’s our job to rise to the moment. (5/7)

I'll close by saying that this pandemic only exacerbated the childcare crisis. I've been working on this issue my entire time in the Senate—the way we do childcare in this country needs an overhaul.

Before I start, I'll just say this issue is personal. Both @SenWarren and I were young moms, our kids were always our first priority. 

When you’re a working mom, you need to feel confident that your kids are safe and cared for.

Also want to point out this crisis has been particularly hard on working moms. The @NYTimes had a feature on this recently, linked it here.

Our plan has three pieces.  

1) Providing support to providers caring for the children of those fighting this pandemic on the frontlines. 
2) Preventing mass permanent closures in the childcare system.
3) Shoring up the system to make it work better in the future.

With more emergency funding, we can avert this crisis. We can allow providers to keep staff on payroll, get PPE, and get assistance for other expenses needed to make childcare work.

Our bill has 50 billion in funding for this effect.

I'll touch on number two in this thread. Mass closures are a serious issue. Childcare has always had thin margins and an early survey indicated nearly half of all providers could not survive a two week shutdown.

I’ve got several bills tackling this problem head on.

You might be thinking that there is a national effort to track how schools are reopening in person so we can reopen as many as possible safely.  

There is not. 
 
Betsy DeVos dropped the ball on this and @SenWarren and I are pushing back. Here's how. [THREAD]

If this sounds like an obvious step to you, that's because it is. 
 
Check out what @SenWarren and I wrote to DeVos, you can read our full letter at the link below. It explains what all this means in more detail: 

https://t.co/rCMMVL5RVB

As far as I see it, DeVos has a choice here, she can choose to do her job or not. 
 
If she wants schools to reopen in person safely, then she should be working with the Education Department to make it happen. Anything else is an abdication of duty.

This position is good news for DeVos, she gets to do less work. For everyone else, it means we’re in the dark about outbreaks in schools and best practices to reopening safely. 
 
@SenWarren and I are on the same page about this, so let’s talk how to make this situation better.

To start with, let's start tracking how many cases are linked to schools and what safeguards schools are putting in place to reopen. 
 
That means coordinating with state and local governments to help with the great work that many are already doing.

Quick background: Last week, Betsy DeVos was asked why a national system doesn't exist. Her response?
 
“I'm not sure there's a role at the department to collect and compile that research.”
 
The dewonkified translation: “I don’t believe in doing it."

This also means creating national reporting standards so it is possible to make comparisons. 

Think how much easier it would be for your kids’ school to make decisions if they knew what health protocols work best and could compare their situation with others across the country.

My guest tonight Chad Dunkley and I connected in the early days of the pandemic, on March 19 the first week of remote work, about the crisis childcare providers and families were facing.

Tonight, I'm looking forward to hearing @POTUS talk more about his plans in the #AmericanFamiliesPlan, and I am so glad that childcare and early education are getting the top-billing these issues deserve.

In addition to childcare and early education, President Biden touched on the progress we’ve made when it comes to combating the coronavirus pandemic, and the progress we still need to make on police reform, gun safety, and tackling climate change.
The bulk of that came from the #AmericanRescuePlan, where we worked together to get $39 billion to stabilize childcare after the hit it took with the pandemic.
Parents, kids, our communities and providers like Chad deserve nothing less.
I'll never forget the emotion in his voice as he shared his story, what was happening to the childcare centers he runs and providers across Minnesota (as revenue plummeted virtually overnight).
New Horizon Academy is one of the many childcare providers that the American Rescue Plan will help. While I wish Chad could have been here in-person, it was an honor for him to be my guest.

As parents know, childcare faced huge challenges before the pandemic. But with COVID it was pushed to the brink and in some cases over the edge. Hearing from childcare providers in Minnesota inspired me to tackle this issue head on.

Chad & I connected in the early days of the pandemic about the crisis MN childcare providers & families were facing. Childcare faced huge challenges before the pandemic, but was pushed to the brink and in some cases over the edge.

Hearing Chad’s story and the experiences in Minnesota inspired me to tackle this and work with partners in congress to deliver historic funding to help stabilize this essential sector.

I want to share something personal for Mental Health Awareness month. We need more understanding and help for the millions of Americans who struggle with mental illness.

I'm not saying that just because I'm a Senator, I'm saying that as someone who has suffered from depression.

I'm grateful I got help, but I share this because I want anyone suffering from a mental health issue to know they are not alone. We can all help break the stigma around talking about this.

But also as a Senator, I recognize my unique position. And I want to use it.

May is American Indian Month in Minnesota. Over the course of this month, find time to support Native businesses and celebrate the immeasurable contributions Native communities bring to our state. I am proud to fight for you every day in the Senate.

I'm announcing I'm rolling out three bills this month addressing the mental health crisis in America. The theme that unites them all: access to resources. 

When I struggled with depression, resources were there for me. Many Americans don't get those, let's change that.

I'll have more to say soon but I want folks to know that even in the midst of this health crisis, I believe there's hope on the horizon for those who struggle with mental illness. But we in the Senate have to do the work to help make that vision a reality. 

Time to get to work.

Did I live happily ever after? Not quite. Mental illness isn't a box where you're healthy or not—it's a spectrum. 

I struggled again in my 30s as a young mom. But after a few years of treatment, I improved and know I can turn to it if I need it again.

Happier IS possible.

When it started in college, I thought it was just a rough patch. But at some point, it got harder to cope with life's daily challenges. 

Everybody who's wrestled with depression has their metaphor, but many can identify with the sensation of color draining out of the world.

When my roommate first talked to me about how I hadn't been myself, I was in denial. But eventually, I realized it made sense to go see a counselor. I didn't know what to expect and honestly, I was embarrassed. 

But the experience changed my life.

Climate change isn't some pie-in-the-sky problem we can deal with later; it's happening right now.
 
So I've been working on a way we can take real action to combat climate change. I'm confident it can pass the Senate and it’s in the budget deal. I want to tell you about it.

Look, I'm not just a Senator. I'm also a grandmother, and our generation owes future generations a planet that's safe to live on.
 
This summer, Congress must get behind a clean electricity standard and pass it into law. I'm going to keep working to make sure we do.

Most Americans already support what we need to do—move to a clean energy future—and fast.
 
The best, most effective way to do this is to invest in a clean electricity standard. How does that work?

The key is important groups have supported clean electricity standards.

Utility companies like how they lowers costs (clean energy is not just clean—it's cheap); labor unions like the jobs created; and environmental groups want to combat climate change with bold legislation.

It’s simple: we set a goal to get to 100% clean electricity (net zero carbon pollution) as soon as possible. And then we help power generators - from the big utilities to your local coop - make the shift to clean power.
 
Sounds great! But can it pass?

Some news: just introduced a bill that will lower the cost of prescription drugs. It's bipartisan and has a real shot of becoming law.
 
Here is what it does in 280 characters:

Right now big drug companies are able to stop others from making low-cost versions of their drugs. They do this by making agreements to not sue a company IF they delay making low-cost versions of medications. It's called "parking".
 
And my bill tackles this problem head on.

I put a bigger summary of the bill below but this is one step forward to tackling a bigger issue. Everyone deserves affordable access to medication.

So Mitch McConnell was droning on about how Dems and Dems alone need to raise the debt ceiling in his floor speech. And it was all to justify blocking us from doing just that. 

This bs is classic Senate doublespeak. I'll let you in on the secret of how it works:

Remember DeJoy, Trump's Postmaster General, who was actively working to undermine @USPS right before a major election?
 
He's still around. He’s also trying to slow down everyone’s mail and raise prices. I'm pushing back.

We need rules of course. But reasonable ones that allow us to get things done. If the rules are allowing the minority to stop anything, maybe it's time to change the rules.

Let's end the filibuster.

I want answers. DeJoy has not even bothered to show if he's done any work on how this new policy impacts groups that rely on the Postal Service. That needs to change.
 
Thanks to @MartinHeinrich, @SenBlumenthal, and @SenatorLujan for working on this with me.

Let's be clear: there's zero excuse for this slowdown. Mail hasn't been this slow since the 1970s.
 
And the people this policy really screws over are the elderly, disabled people, veterans, and rural and Tribal communities. USPS is often a lifeline for these folks.

And that's exactly what the GOP is doing. There's no way to defend sending the US into financial default. It makes no sense, unless you care more about getting on Fox News instead of being responsible.

So the GOP weaponizes rules and hides behind how confusing they are instead.

Let's say you hold a position that is impossible to justify.

Ridiculous Senate rules give you a way out! Instead of arguing your point, you can hide behind fancy sounding procedures like the filibuster to obscure your real position.

See? Doublespeak.
We should abolish the debt ceiling limit. When the United States has bills to pay we should pay them, period.

Millions of Americans struggle with their mental health.

I’m a U.S. Senator. And I’ve struggled with depression. Because it’s mental health awareness month, I’m sharing my story here.
Thanks for listening.

I have several bills that would make a big difference. I'll share more details very soon but the big theme is access.
 
When I was ready to get help for my depression, I had resources. That’s not true for everyone, and we need to change that.

I've experienced depression twice in my life.

The first time I was in college.  At first I thought it was just a rough patch. As time went on, it became harder to cope.

There’s no magic cure for depression, and no one bill will fix everything.

But we can make progress, and help more people get help and support, and that’s what matters.

I share this because 

1) I want to let people know they are not alone. We can all work to break the stigma around talking about this.
 
And 2) I'm a U.S. Senator, and I'm using my position to make positive change.
My roommate tried to talk to me about it, but I was in denial. Eventually, I realized I needed help, and went to see a counselor. That experience changed my life. Happier IS possible.

When I was a young mom in my 30s, I struggled again. I remember my heart breaking when our son said "Mom, are you OK?"

I got help sooner this time, and I with treatment and care got better.

Last year when I shared this story, we were at a different place with mental health in the Senate. But the conversation has advanced.
 
There are now two committees that are actively working in a bipartisan way to pass mental health legislation.

Seven weeks into pregnancy, Yeni rushed to the emergency room in Luling, Texas because she couldn’t breathe. Doctors told her she was experiencing a ‘threatened miscarriage’ and her blood pressure was 185/98.

Yeni was high risk. She had diabetes and a history of pulmonary edema.

Yeni did everything she could to manage her pregnancy and follow her doctors instructions. She woke up one night at 22 weeks pregnant, and couldn’t breathe.

In the emergency room, her blood pressure was all over the place.

175/108.
219/126.
233/133.

OB-GYNs agree that termination should have been discussed with her – but Texas passed abortion restrictions that put her health care providers in a giant grey area.

They had to be thinking: Could I go to jail for giving the medical advice I’ve been trained to deliver?

Nobody discussed her options with her. Even in the emergency room when doctors acknowledged she could die, termination wasn’t an option.

Dobbs was decided two weeks before she died. Four outside experts agreed that Yeni’s death was entirely preventable.

But that wasn’t the last time Yeni suffered complications. She woke up again two months later, unable to breathe.

Paramedics measured her blood pressure at 213/146 – dangerously high.

They prepped her to be transported to the hospital.

She was transferred to Ascension Seton Medical Center Austin. Upon arrival, doctors determined Yeni was at high risk for “clinical decompensation” – in laymen’s terms: death.

Doctors were able to stabilize her, but they sent her home without discussing all of her options.

The crisis over the flags flown outside Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito’s homes – and his entirely unsurprising refusal to recuse from pending January 6-related cases – perfectly illustrates why we need to expand the Court.
 
Let’s review.

A couple of weeks ago, it was reported that for a few days between the insurrection and President Biden’s inauguration, the Alitos flew an upside-down US flag outside their Northern Virginia home. https://t.co/HUtPeyhmXX

The only practical way for dealing with a danger like Alito on the bench is to expand the Supreme Court.
 
The Constitution explicitly gives Congress the power to set the number of Justices, and it has been changed a number of times over our history.

The only way to combat the danger from Alito – and his fellow Justice Clarence Thomas – is to increase the number of Justices on the Court so that extremists like Alito cannot determine the cases that determine the law for our country.

More recently, it’s been used by January 6 insurrectionists and other extremists.
 
The concept of an Appeal to Heaven goes back to the philosopher John Locke, who was a major inspiration for the American revolutionaries.

In 2023, at the Alitos’ vacation home, they flew a second insurrectionist flag called the “Appeal to Heaven” or “Pine Tree Flag”, which has a glorious history in the American Revolution, where it symbolized the justness of the war against unjust British rulers.

The Alitos were embracing election denial and insurrection.

Mrs. Alito told a reporter that the flag was “an international signal of distress” – the flag expressed the view that the U.S. was in a condition of distress because Biden — not Trump — was being inaugurated.

But in 2023, the Alitos are in effect declaring the Biden administration illegitimate and worth going to war against.
 
That is a danger to our democracy and a profound crisis. Especially when one of you sits on the nation’s highest court.

So the Appeal to Heaven flag is a declaration that rulers have abused their power and it is a call to arms against that government.
 
When flown by George Washington, it is a glorious rebellion against unjust British rulers.

In Locke’s philosophy, the Appeal to Heaven is what individuals and whole peoples may do when they judge that their rulers have abused their power and need to be replaced, including by violent rebellion.
 
See: January 6th.

The Supreme Court is an essential foundation of our democracy and the rule of law. 

It is broken.

So what do we do about it? By rights, Justice Alito should resign – that is how serious this is.

But of course, he is not going to do that.

The upside-down American flag was widely adopted by the Stop the Steal movement after the 2020 election, including some January 6 insurrectionists, to express the manifestly false belief that Biden had stolen the election from Trump.

As many have argued, Justice Alito should recuse himself from the pending January 6-related Supreme Court cases.
 
But to no one’s surprise, Alito has announced that he is not going to do that.

There should be a stronger Supreme Court code of ethics, and there is a bill to do that. We should absolutely pass that bill.
 
But it’s not enough.
 
Alito is not going to be impeached and removed, which requires 67 votes in the Senate.

Because there is no judge to arbitrate between a people and their rulers, appealing to heaven for the justness of your cause is all you can do. But that also means that you are putting yourself in a state of war with your rulers. 
 
Locke justifies rebellion.

For over 100 years it was the official policy of the United States to forcibly separate Native children from their families and Tribes and remove them to boarding schools. These children were stripped of their language, culture, and family and Tribal ties.
The incredible resilience of Native peoples, even as the United States government tried to erase and eradicate their identities, is deeply inspiring.

My hope is that POTUS’s formal apology will help us continue down the path of healing.

And, it is an opportunity for us to renew our commitment to strengthen Tribal sovereignty and deepen our respect for our trust and treaty obligations to Tribal Nations.

Many children were physically and emotionally abused, and many died. This isn’t ancient history; this was the policy of the federal government until the 1960s.

This unspeakable tragedy is not well understood by most Americans, even as impacts of this trauma live on to this day.

I live in Minneapolis, the birthplace of the American Indian Movement, and home of the National Native American Boarding School Healing Coalition. I was blessed to visit the Coalition with @SecDebHaaland and @LtGovFlanagan, and hear the stories of survivors of boarding schools.

This is why it is so important that President Biden is formally apologizing to Native peoples for this great injustice. This apology would not have happened without the leadership of @SecDebHaaland, whose own grandparents were stolen and taken away to boarding schools.

One thing is clear: Legislation is necessary to fix this unforeseen issue with the 1948 law.

This bill would ensure that payments to these three counties are maintained at current levels so they can best serve their local communities.
 
Without action, this vital source of revenue, which supports services like emergency management and road maintenance, will decrease.

The bipartisan Thye-Blatnik Act of 1948 is unique in that payments to these counties depend upon appraisals conducted every 10 years.
 
But in 2018, that appraisal led to a big decrease, which just doesn’t make sense for this one-of-a-kind wilderness area.

Without action, communities in Northern Minnesota will face a serious budget crunch. That could mean allowing roads to crumble and essential public safety services to be cut. It could even result in property tax increases that could force long-time residents to sell their homes.

Today I called the Bureau of Prisons to get some answers about closing the Federal Prison Camp in Duluth.

I’m not sold on their rationale for closing, nor their decision making process. I’m going to keep pushing for answers, especially for the workers who could lose their jobs.

I don’t think American voters sent everybody to Congress for this kind of nonsense. I think they expected us to get our damn jobs done.

This is not what the election was about.

Everyone should be able to retire with dignity. For years, 21,000 Minnesota firefighters, teachers, postal workers + police officers have faced Social Security cuts because of outdated laws.

Last night, we fixed that.

Proud to support the Social Security Fairness Act.
